To the Stars |} * Note: Back when "Macross" was first put in production, the anime was originally going to end with a total of 23 episodes, but due to popularity, it was expanded to end with a total of 36 episodes. ==Sequels and prequel== A number of sequels and one prequel to the series have been produced. ''For more information, see: [[Macross#Series chronology|Macross – Series Chronology]]'' ==Production== The series title uses the name of the main spacecraft (which is usually shortened to ''[[SDF-1 Macross]]'' as it is Earth's first ''Super Dimension Fortress''). The original name for the ''Macross'' project was ''Battle City Megaload'' (or ''Battle City Megaroad'', as the Japanese transliteration to either {{angbr|l}} or {{angbr|r}} gives the title a double meaning in reference to the story line: ''Megaload'', referring to the spacecraft containing an entire city of people; and ''Megaroad'', referring to the long journey through space back to Earth).{{cite web | title=Translation & Cultural Notes | url=http://www.animeigo.com/Liner/MACROSS.t#1 | work=Super Dimension Fortress Macross Liner Notes | publisher=[[AnimEigo]] | date=21 December 2001 | accessdate=26 April 2009 | quote=Comments attributed to Kawamori Shoji in the Macross liner notes are drawn from Nanda, Mamoru (1983) Best Hit Series: Super Dimension Fortress Macross: Macross Graffiti, Akita Shoten, Tokyo. | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813121403/http://www.animeigo.com/Liner/MACROSS.t#1 | archivedate=13 August 2009 | df=dmy-all }} However, the director of [[Big West Advertising|Big West]], one of the later sponsors of the project, was a fan of Shakespeare and wanted the series and the spacecraft to be named ''[[Macbeth]]'' ({{nihongo||マクベス|Makubesu}}). A compromise was made with the title ''Macross'' ({{nihongo||マクロス|Makurosu}}) due to its similar pronunciation to ''Macbeth'' in Japanese and because it still contained connotations to the original title. The word ''Macross'' also comes from a wordplay combination of the prefix "macro" in reference to its massive size (though when compared with the alien ships in the series, it is only a relatively small capital ship) and the distance they must cross.Super Dimension Fortress Macross: The Making of Macross. Pages 203–246. ''Macross Perfect Memory''. Reference Book. 260 A4 pages. Minori Library, Japan. Y2800. 1983, 10 October. "Super Dimension Fortress" prefix ("Chō Jikū Yōsai") is a wordplay on an intermediary working title for the series, which was originally "Super Dreadnought Fortress Macross" ("Chō Dokyū Yōsai Makurosu"). Originally proposed in 1980 and greatly inspired by [[Mobile Suit Gundam]] (1979-1980),{{cite web | title=Translation & Cultural Notes | url=http://www.animeigo.com/Liner/MACROSS.t#1 | work=The Super Dimension Fortress Macross Liner Notes | publisher=[[AnimEigo]] | date=2001-12-21 | accessdate=2014-09-18 | quote=According to the liner notes of the AnimEigo DVD release of the Macross TV series ''Gunsight One'' was also the fanzine title of the ''Gundam'' fan club that creator Shoji Kawamori, character designer Haruhiko Mikimoto, and writer Hiroshi Oonogi (members number 1, 2, and 3 of said club) founded while they were students at Keio University in Japan... | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813121403/http://www.animeigo.com/Liner/MACROSS.t#1 | archivedate=13 August 2009 | df=dmy-all }} the show created by [[Studio Nue]][http://www.macross.co.jp/ Super Dimension Fortress Macross: Series Outline. ''Macross Official Website''. Series Section. 04-09-09] (from an original concept by newcomer member [[Shoji Kawamori]]) was initially sponsored by a group called the "Wiz" (''Uizu'') Corporation that was prepared to fund a 48-episode run. "Wiz" wanted to produce the Sci-Fi show as an [[outer space]] comedy, but this clashed with Studio Nue's original idea of a more serious and epic "[[space opera]]" storyline. The resulting animosity between both companies made the initial pre-production of the series very difficult and full of delays.Super Dimension Fortress Macross: Production Notes. Page 247. ''Macross Perfect Memory''. Reference Book. 260 A4 pages. Minori Library, Japan. Y2800. 1983, 10 October. However, by 1981 Wiz had gone out of business and the "Megaload/Megaroad" (''Macross'') project seemed to be in permanent hiatus. Studio Nue bought the rights of the show from "Wiz" and searched for a sponsor with no avail. [[Big West Advertising|Big West]], an advertising agency looking to branch out into animation sponsorship, approached Studio Nue about the project and agreed to sponsor it. Big West insisted on a leaner budget, not convinced that the show would pan out as profitable and pared the episode count to 27 episodes (meaning the show would have ended with the battle against [[Boddole Zer]]'s fleet). Even then, Big West found that the show was going to run more expensive than it had bargained for, and to secure more money, entered into a partnership with animation studio [[Tatsunoko Production]] which included international distribution (what would culminate in the creation of the "[[Robotech]]" adaptation a few years later). Among other production headaches, the master copy of one nearly-completed episode was reportedly accidentally left on a train by a courier, forcing the members of the production staff themselves to search for the footage – otherwise they would have to re-animate it all, at a considerable cost in time and money. Eventually they found the reel, and so disaster was averted.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} When Macross debuted on 3 October 1982 (with only three episodes made so far) its stunning success among Japanese television audiences convinced Big West to approve an extension to 36 episodes, allowing the staff to end with the "two years after" story arc. [[Studio Nue]] was unable to carry all of the animation work itself at the time (although the success of Macross meant that it was able to do so with nearly all of its other animation projects), and so work was contracted out to a number of satellite studios, including [[Artland (anime studio)|Artland]] ([[Haruhiko Mikimoto]]'s employer), the nascent [[Anime International Company|AIC]] and [[Gainax]] studios, as well as the [[Tatsunoko Production|Tatsunoko]]-supplied [[AnimeFriend]] and [[Star Pro]]. AnimeFriend and Star Pro are infamously notorious among fans of the show for having brought in very spotty, off-model and continuity error-laden animation work. There were plans for a splashy ending to the series, one that would have shown major characters Misa Hayase and Hikaru Ichijo blasting off in the colonization ship ''[[SDF-2 Megaroad-01]]'', but the sequence was scrapped due to lack of time and budget. However, due to fan demand this sequence was later used in the ''[[Macross Flashback 2012]]'' OVA released in 1987.{{cite web | title=Translation & Cultural Notes | url=http://www.animeigo.com/Liner/MACROSS.t#1 | work=The Super Dimension Fortress Macross Liner Notes | publisher=[[AnimEigo]] | date=21 December 2001 | accessdate=26 April 2009 | quote=Originally, the creators wanted to end the series with the launch of the SDF-2 and the newly-wed Ichijo Misa in her new captain's uniform. Mechanical designer Miyatake Kazutaka and character designer Mikimoto Haruhiko even drew new designs appropriate for the occasion. Unfortunately, the sequence was never animated. The creators finally got the chance to redesign and animate the SDF-2 Megaroad launch (along with the Minmay Sayonara Concert that was planned but canceled for the ''Do You Remember Love?'' movie ending) four years later. The conclusion of Hikaru, Misa, and Minmay's story appears in the 1987 music video ''The Super Dimension Fortress Macross: Flash Back 2012.'' | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813121403/http://www.animeigo.com/Liner/MACROSS.t#1 | archivedate=13 August 2009 | df=dmy-all }}Best Hit Series: ''The Super Dimension Fortress Macross: Flash Back 2012 Graffiti''. Shougakukan, Japan. Y910. 1987. ''The Super Dimension Fortress Macross'' was produced as the first of the three ''Super Dimension'' mecha anime television series in Japan. It was followed by ''[[The Super Dimension Century Orguss]]'' (1983) and ''[[The Super Dimension Cavalry Southern Cross]]'' (1984). These shows were related in name only.{{cite book |title=The Anime Encyclopedia, Revised and expanded edition |last1=Clements |first1=Johnathan |last2=McCarthy |first2=Helen |pages=468–469 |isbn=1-933330-10-4}}{{cite book |title=The Anime Encyclopedia, Revised and expanded edition |last1=Clements |first1=Johnathan |last2=McCarthy |first2=Helen |pages=598–599 |isbn=1-933330-10-4}} ==Media== ===Anime=== {{main|List of The Super Dimension Fortress Macross episodes}} In 1984, [[Harmony Gold USA|Harmony Gold]] licensed the first ''Macross'' series from Tatsunoko and planned to dub the series on home video. In 1985, Harmony Gold edited and rewrote the series with ''[[The Super Dimension Cavalry Southern Cross]]'' and ''[[Genesis Climber Mospeada]]'' into ''[[Robotech]]'', to syndicate on weekday television and to promote a [[Revell]] model line. ''Robotech'''s credits listed only the English adaptation's production crew and two Tatsunoko producers. In 1999, Harmony Gold asserted it had exclusive rights to the "distribution of the Macross television series and the right to create and authorize the sale of merchandise based on such series" outside Japan, and began sending cease-and-desist letters to import toy dealers, temporarily barring ''Macross''-related merchandise from North America.{{cite news|title=Harmony Gold bars Macross Imports|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=16 April 2002|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2002-04-16/harmony-gold-bars-macross-imports |accessdate=27 January 2007}} The merchandise has since been imported again by the same toy dealers in direct sales, and Harmony Gold has sublicensed additional material for North American retail distribution. In 2000, Big West and Studio Nue took [[Tatsunoko Production]]s to the [[Tokyo District Court]] over who had the rights to the first ''Macross'' series, due to Harmony Gold's attempt to bar Japanese Macross merchandise in North America the previous year. During production, Big West entered into a partnership with Tatsunoko to assist in the production of the series in a deal where it acquired the license to distribute the show worldwide (i.e., outside Japan), as well as earning some royalties to the merchandise. Tatsunoko then sub-licensed ''Macross'' to [[Harmony Gold USA]] in 1984. In 2002, the Tokyo District Court ruled that Big West/Studio Nue is the sole owner of the original character and mecha designs for the first series,{{cite news|title=Macross Lawsuit|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=26 February 2002|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2002-02-26/macross-lawsuit|accessdate=27 January 2007}} while that same court ruled in 2003 that Tatsunoko owned the production rights to the first series.{{cite news|title=Tatsunoko Wins "Author's Right" to Macross|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=2003-10-14|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2003-01-20/tatsunoko-wins-author's-right-to-macross |accessdate=27 January 2007}}{{cite news|title=Tatsunoko Wins Macross Lawsuit|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=23 February 2004|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2004-02-23/tatsunoko-wins-macross-lawsuit |accessdate=27 January 2007}} In the autumn of 1984, Harmony Gold released the first English-language version of ''Macross'': an English-dubbed VHS video release containing unedited video footage of the first three episodes with a new English theme song, adapted dialogue scripts, and several name changes (which were later used in ''Robotech'', aside from Rick Yamada/Hikaru Ichijyo, who became Rick Hunter). This release was canceled after one volume when production of the ''Robotech'' adaptation began. The first episode of this 1984 English dubbing was later released as an extra in the ''Robotech Legacy Collection 5'' and ''Robotech Protoculture Collection'' DVD releases, and is also included in the first volume of [[ADV Films]]' 2006 release of ''Macross''. [[Streamline Pictures]] then released ''Robotech Perfect Collection: Macross'' on VHS in the summer of 1994, combining two English subtitled episodes of ''Macross'' and the corresponding dubbed episodes of the ''Robotech'' adaptation in each volume. This was the first English subtitling for ''Macross'', but it contained unedited video footage with incomplete and mistranslated English subtitles and was cancelled after eight volumes and 16 episodes. The series was originally licensed in North America by [[AnimEigo]], who restored the series and released it unedited on DVD with Japanese audio and English subtitles.{{cite web |url=http://www.animeigo.com/Products/MACROSS.t |title=SuperRestored Television Series Macross |publisher=[[AnimEigo]] |accessdate=26 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227055636/http://www.animeigo.com/Products/MACROSS.t |archivedate=27 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }} At first a limited edition pre-order boxset across nine discs was released on 21 December 2001. Preorders were available on AnimEigo's web store. Three smaller boxsets, each comprising three discs, were released from 10 September 2002.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B0000B1ODL |title=Macross, Super Dimensional Fortress Box Set 1 (eps 1–12) |publisher=[[Amazon.ca]] |accessdate=26 December 2008}}{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B0000B1ODN |title=Macross, Super Dimensional Fortress Box Set 2 (ep.13–24) |publisher=[[Amazon.ca]] |accessdate=26 December 2008}}{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B0000B1ODO |title=3pc Box: Set 3 – Macross |publisher=[[Amazon.ca]] |accessdate=26 December 2008}} Finally, AnimEigo released nine individual volumes. In 2003 [[Madman Entertainment]] released a six-disc [[PAL]] format version of this edition entitled ''Macross Ultimate Collection''. In the summer of 2005, [[ADV Films]] announced that it would be releasing an English dub of ''Macross'' on 10 January 2006. This is the first uncut, unedited English dub for ''Super Dimension Fortress Macross'', and featured [[Mari Iijima]] returning to reprise the role of Lynn Minmay.{{cite news|title=Mari Iijima, the Japanese voice of Minmay, will play the same role in the English dub|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=22 October 2005|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/article.php?id=7659|accessdate=19 November 2005}} However, the voice actors used in the dub were not the same as those used in the 1985 [[Robotech]] adaptation.[http://www25.advfilms.com/titles/macross/ ADV Films Official ''Macross'' English Dub Page.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711130623/http://www25.advfilms.com/titles/macross/ |date=11 July 2009 }}[http://www25.advfilms.com/titles/macross/cast_txt.html English/Japanese Cast Information. 04-09-09] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805002542/http://www25.advfilms.com/titles/macross/cast_txt.html |date=5 August 2009 }} This version was released by [[Hulu]] for online streaming in the United States in February 2010 and was removed in February 2013.{{cite news | title = 1st ''Macross'' Series Streaming with English Dub on Hulu | url = http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-02-10/1st-macross-series-streaming-with-english-dub-on-hulu | publisher = [[Anime News Network]] | date = 10 February 2010 | accessdate = 14 February 2010}} On 25 July 2014, [[Lionsgate Home Entertainment]] announced that they would release a new ''Robotech'' DVD collection entitled ''Robotech: The Classic Collection'' exclusively through [[Amazon.com]]. Volume 1 contains the first 18 episodes of ''Robotech: The Macross Saga'' as it was originally broadcast, and the first 18 episodes of ''Macross'', completely uncut and presented in both Japanese with English subtitles and the ADV English dub.{{cite news | title = Press Release: Robotech Classic Collection | url = http://www.robotech.com/news/viewarticle.php?id=518 | publisher = Robotech.com | date = 25 July 2014 | accessdate = 26 July 2014}} ===Manga=== A new [[manga]] adaptation of the first TV series called {{nihongo|'''''Super Dimension Fortress Macross: The First'''''|Choujikuu要塞マクロスファースト|Choujikuu Yousai Macross the First}} was released in Japan during 2009. It is a comic format alternate telling of the events in ''The Super Dimension Fortress Macross'' (with modern character and mecha designs) that was being serialized in the ''Macross Ace'' manga magazine until its cancellation, being moved to "Newtype Ace" manga magazine, where it's being currently serialized. The artist for the new manga series is Haruhiko Mikimoto, who was the character designer for the original ''Macross''.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-11-21/designer-haruhiko-mikimoto-to-draw-new-macross-manga|title=Designer Haruhiko Mikimoto to Draw New Macross Manga (Updated)|date=21 November 2008|accessdate=12 November 2009|work=|publisher=Anime News Network}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2009-06-28/new-macross-manga-launches-in-japan-macross-ace-mag|title=New Macross Manga Launches in Japan's Macross Ace Mag|date=28 June 2009|accessdate=12 November 2009|work=|publisher=Anime News Network}} ===Video games=== A game based on the TV series called ''[[The Super Dimension Fortress Macross (Family Computer)|The Super Dimension Fortress Macross]]'' was released for the Japanese [[Nintendo Entertainment System|Nintendo Family Computer]] console in 1985 by video game company [[Namco]]. Years later [[Namco Bandai Games|Bandai]] released ''[[The Super Dimension Fortress Macross (PlayStation 2 game)|The Super Dimension Fortress Macross]]'' 3D shooting game in October 2003 in Japan for the [[Sony]] [[PlayStation 2]] console. This game had levels based in both the TV series and its [[The Super Dimension Fortress Macross: Do You Remember Love?|movie adaptation]]. More recently, a new 3D [[shooting game]] called ''[[Macross Ace Frontier]]'' included several elements from the original series. It was developed by [[Artdink]] for the Sony [[PlayStation Portable|PSP]] and was released in 2008. ==Reception== In the ''Anime Encyclopedia'', authors [[Jonathan Clements]] and [[Helen McCarthy]] called the series "One of the three unassailable pillars of anime sci-fi, pioneering the tripartite winning formula of songs, battling robot-planes and tense relationships".{{cite book |title=The Anime Encyclopedia, Revised and expanded edition |last1=Clements |first1=Johnathan |last2=McCarthy |first2=Helen |pages=385–386 |isbn=1-933330-10-4}} For the video game ''[[Devil May Cry 4]]'' motion and voice actor Reuben Langdon was told to make cockier than his younger persona albeit more mature. Despite the staff's concerns for the difficulties of such portrayal, Langdon had no issues after choosing [[Roy Focker]] from ''The Super Dimension Fortress Macross'' as his character model and noting he had almost the same age as Dante during production of the game.{{cite web|author=Langdon, Reuben |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N8ySzx_fmjk|title=DMC4 Nero |publisher=Youtube|date=14 January 2013 |accessdate=30 May 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.macross.co.jp/ Official Macross website]{{jp icon}} * {{ann|anime|355}} * {{IMDb title|0142183}} * [http://www.mahq.net/animation/macross/macross.htm Macross episode reviews] * [http://macross.anime.net/wiki/Category:The_Super_Dimension_Fortress_Macross Macross Compendium] * [http://www.macross2.net/m3/sdfmacross/sdfmacross-index.html Macross Mecha Manual]—A website profiling the fictional vehicles of the Macross series * [http://www.macrosschronicle.com Macross Chronicle]—News and Info of the Macross Series (In Spanish) {{s-start}} {{s-new|first}} {{s-ttl|title=Super Dimension ''series''|years=''Super Dimension Fortress Macross''}} {{s-aft|after=''[[Super Dimension Century Orguss]]''}} {{s-end}} {{Macross series|state=off}} {{Robotech|state=collapsed}} {{Tatsunoko Production}} {{Artland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Super Dimension Fortress Macross, The}} [[Category:1982 anime television series]] [[Category:Animated space adventure television series]] [[Category:Anime with original screenplays]] [[Category:Aviation television series]] [[Category:Kadokawa Shoten manga]] [[Category:Macross anime and manga]] [[Category:Madman Entertainment anime]] [[Category:Mainichi Broadcasting System shows]] [[Category:Mecha anime and manga]] [[Category:Shōnen manga]] [[Category:Super Dimension]] [[Category:Tatsunoko Production]] [[Category:Television series set in 2009]] [[Category:Japanese idols in anime and manga]] [[Category:Fiction about size change]] [[Category:Television series set in 1999]]

'''''Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist''''' is an [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[stealth game|stealth]] [[video game]] developed by [[Ubisoft Toronto]] and published by [[Ubisoft]]. The sixth installment of the ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell]]'' series, it is the sequel of ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Conviction|Splinter Cell: Conviction]]''. The game was released worldwide for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Wii U]], and [[Xbox 360]] in August 2013. In the game, players control [[Sam Fisher (Splinter Cell)|Sam Fisher]], a spymaster working for the Fourth Echelon, in a mission to stop the Engineers, a group of terrorists which is trying to coerce the United States into recalling all of its troops stationed abroad. ''Blacklist''{{'s}} gameplay is similar to its predecessors, with players tasked with completing objectives and defeating enemies. ''Blacklist'' marks the return of the asymmetrical multiplayer mode Spies vs. Mercs, which was introduced in ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Pandora Tomorrow|Pandora Tomorrow]]''.
It is the first title developed by Ubisoft Toronto, a studio founded by Ubisoft in 2009. The game was directed by Maxime Béland, who had worked on ''Conviction'', and produced by [[Jade Raymond]]. The game endeavors to combine elements of its predecessors, including the action focus of ''Conviction'' and the stealth focus of the older games. To prepare for this game, Béland studied reviews and feature lists of the latter. ''Blacklist'' is the first ''Splinter Cell'' game starring [[Eric Johnson (actor)|Eric Johnson]] as Sam Fisher, since series veteran [[Michael Ironside]] was unable to perform motion capture for the game. The Toronto studio focused on the game's Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 versions, and its later-announced Wii U version was developed by [[Ubisoft Shanghai]], which also developed the game's multiplayer.
''Blacklist''{{'s}} pre-release reception was generally positive, despite criticism of its new voice actor. The game received generally positive reviews when it was released, with praise for its level design, story, gameplay, combat, soundtrack and multiplayer mode. However, criticism was directed at its dated graphics, lack of challenge and ending. It failed to meet Ubisoft's sales expectations, with sales of two million copies three months after its release.
==Gameplay== [[File:Splinter Cell Blacklist screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A man hiding from a soldier by hanging from a ledge|Screenshot of Fisher evading enemies by hanging from a building ledge]] In ''Blacklist'', players assume control of series protagonist [[Sam Fisher (Splinter Cell)|Sam Fisher]] as he seeks to stop a terrorist group called the Engineers. The gameplay emphasizes [[stealth video game|stealth]], and utilizes the [[Virtual camera system#Third-person view|third-person perspective]]. During the game, players can rotate its camera, run, crouch and leap over obstacles. Since ''Blacklist'' intended to continue the "aggressive stealth" of ''Conviction'' while retaining the traditional stealth features of the older games, it combines action and stealth,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/splinter-cell-blacklist-trailer-reveals-fishers-abilities-mostly-sneaking-and-shooting/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist trailer reveals Fisher's abilities - mostly sneaking and shooting|first=Phil|last=Savage|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=April 15, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> and allows players to use different approaches and methods to complete objectives and defeat enemies. Players can complete levels without being noticed by the non-playable characters' [[artificial intelligence]] by taking cover or using other traditional stealth methods. If the player chooses to kill enemies, other enemies are alerted when they see their companions' dead bodies. To avoid this, players can hide corpses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/06/04/e3-2012-splinter-cell-blacklist-fearing-sam-fisher|title=E3 2012: Splinter Cell Blacklist - Fearing Sam Fisher|first=Richard|last=George|work=[[IGN]]|date=June 4, 2012|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> Fisher can also create a strategically advantageous dark environment by destroying nearby lights,<ref name="GG">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/goodgame/stories/s3834879.htm|title=Good Game Stories: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist|work=[[Good Game (television series)|Good Game]]|date=August 27, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> and is equipped with customizable night-vision and sonar goggles to detect enemies in darkness and see through walls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-03-14-heres-how-splinter-cell-blacklists-night-vision-mode-looks|title=Here's how Splinter Cell: Blacklist's night-vision mode looks|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=March 14, 2015|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/splinter_cell_blacklist/b/xbox360/archive/2013/06/19/playing-splinter-cell-blacklist-with-friends-and-enemies.aspx|title=Playing Splinter Cell: Blacklist With Friends And Enemies|first=Kyle|last=Hilliard|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=June 19, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> He also has the Tri-Rotor, a compact surveillance drone which can spy on enemies, create distractions, give electric shocks, and self-destruct to kill enemies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/splinter-cell-blacklist-video-shows-the-different-play-styles-ghost-assault-and-er-panther/|title=Splinter Cell Blacklist video shows the different play-styles: Ghost, Assault and, er, Panther|first=Tom|last=Sykes|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=March 22, 2013|accessdate=July 8, 2015}}</ref>
Players can play a more aggressive run-and-gun game by using gadgets and weapons to eliminate enemies. They can interact with environmental objects, such as ledges and [[zip-line]]s, to navigate levels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/new-splinter-cell-blacklist-video-features-ziplines-human-shields-a-crossbow/|title=New Splinter Cell Blacklist video features ziplines, human shields, a crossbow|first=Tom|last=Sykes|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=February 3, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> ''Conviction''{{'s}} mark-and-execute system returns in ''Blacklist'', with refinements and additions to allow players to mark several targets. When they attack, they can kill all marked targets instantly.<ref name="KillMotion">{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/preview-killing-in-motion-in-splinter-cell-blacklist-229417.phtml|title=Preview: Killing in motion in Splinter Cell: Blacklist|first=Bob|last=Muir|work=[[Destructoid]]|date=June 13, 2012|accessdate=July 8, 2015}}</ref> Improvements made the system work more fluidly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/splinter-cell-blacklist-e3-trailer-features-graphic-violence-goggles-and-a-new-sam-fisher/|title=Splinter Cell Blacklist E3 trailer features graphic violence, goggles, and a new Sam Fisher|first=Chris|last=Thursten |date=June 5, 2012|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> A variety of enemies (including soldiers and dogs) are encountered in the game, following the protagonist and alerting their companions. Players have the option to kill them, leave them untouched, or incapacitate them,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/08/05/why-splinter-cell-blacklist-is-throwing-pacifist-players-a-bone|title=Why Splinter Cell: Blacklist Is Throwing Pacifist Players A Bone|first=Luke|last=Reilly|work=[[IGN]]|date=August 1, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> and the game classifies their choices in one of three categories: Ghost (stealthy play), Panther (stealthy, aggressive play), and Assault (aggressive play).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2013/03/22/new-splinter-cell-blacklist-video-shows-off-abandoned-mill-level.aspx|title=New Splinter Cell Blacklist Video Shows Off Abandoned Mill Level|first=Louis |last=Garcia|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=March 22, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2013}}</ref>
When players kill (or avoid) targets and complete objectives, [[experience (gaming)|experience points]] and money are awarded to buy (or improve) weapons, and upgrade the ''Paladin'' airship and Sam's suit and equipment;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/splinter-cell-blacklist-hands-on-perfectionist-mode-takes-fisher-back-to-basics/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist hands-on - Perfectionist mode takes Fisher back to basics|first=Jon|last=Blyth |date=April 18, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> the upgrades improve efficiency in completing missions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5980222/splinter-cell-blacklist-a-pleasing-if-somewhat-hollow-return-to-form|title=Splinter Cell Blacklist: A Pleasing If Somewhat Hollow Return To The Form|work=[[Kotaku]]|first=Kirk|last=Hamilton|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> Experience gained depends on the difficulty level and how the game is played; the greater the stealth, the greater the reward.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/02/04/rediscovering-sam-fishers-roots-in-splinter-cell-blacklist/|title=Rediscovering Sam Fisher's Roots In Splinter Cell Blacklist|first=David|last=Hinkle|work=[[Joystiq]]|date=February 4, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> According to Ubisoft Toronto, the system, known as "universal economy", was intended to satisfy players; every action has a corresponding reward.<ref name="Poly1">{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/7/11/4492014/splinter-cell-blacklist-prevew-single-player|title=Finance black ops with stellar kills and stealth in Splinter Cell: Blacklist|first=Megan|last=Farokhmanesh|date=July 11, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]}}</ref>
The ''Paladin'' is the game's hub. Between missions, players can interact with crew members on the ship and view the game's objectives.<ref name="GG"/> Crew members also offer the protagonist side missions to complete.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/1/30/3931136/splinter-cell-blacklists-forward-progress|title=Splinter Cell Blacklist's Forward Progress|first=Arthur|last=Gies|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> Before a mission Fisher can deploy the strategic mission interface, allowing players to see enemy positions and plan attacks and routes. Players can also use the interface to access multiplayer modes and missions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/previews/e3-2012-splinter-cell-blacklist-preview|title=E3 2012: Splinter Cell Blacklist preview|first=Mike|last=Meredith|work=GameZone|date=June 7, 2012|accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref>
Although the game has interrogation sequences involving questioning (or torturing) targets, it does not feature ''Conviction''{{'s}} interactive torture scenes. Players can still decide whether to spare their targets or kill them after interrogation,<ref name="KTorture">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5980350/splinter-cell-blacklist-wont-have-interactive-torture-but-itll-still-have-interrogations|title=Splinter Cell Blacklist Won't Have Interactive Torture But It'll Still Have Interrogation|first=Kirk|last=Hamilton|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=January 30, 2016}}</ref> and these decisions influence the relationship between Fisher and other crew members.<ref name="Poly1"/>
''Blacklist'' has platform-specific features, including voice integration with Xbox 360's Kinect peripheral which allows players to distract enemies before attacking them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/117608-E3-Kill-With-Voice-Commands-in-Splinter-Cell-Blacklist|title=E3: Kill With Voice Commands In Splinter Cell: Blacklist|first=John|last=Funk|work=[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]|date=June 5, 2012|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> A player can also use the Kinect sensor to control the protagonist with their body instead of the Xbox 360 controller.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2309474/Splinter-Cell-Blacklist-abilities-trailer.html|title=It's a brand new Sam: Watch the latest Splinter Cell Blacklist trailer (Xbox 360 / PS3/ PC /Wii U)|first=Talal|last=Musa|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=April 15, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> In the Wii U version, the Gamepad controller's touchscreen is an interface, accessing gadgets and other features from the protagonist's arm-mounted computer (OPSAT), and incorporating screen and motion controls to highlight enemies with thermal vision when using Killing in Motion. The Wii U version was not shipped with the game's cooperative mode.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2013/08/ubisoft_the_wii_u_gamepad_feels_like_a_natural_extension_in_splinter_cell_blacklist|title=Ubisoft: The Wii U GamePad "Feels Like a Natural Extension" in Splinter Cell Blacklist|first=Thomas|last=Whitehead|work=Nintendo Life|date=August 3, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref>
==={{anchor|Multiplayer}}Multiplayer modes=== The "Spies vs. Mercs" competitive mode introduced in ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Pandora Tomorrow|Pandora Tomorrow]]'' again appears in ''Blacklist''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schramm |first=Mike |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2012/09/11/splinter-cell-blacklist-aims-to-take-convictions-promise-to-th/ |title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist aims to take Conviction's promise to the next level and then some |work=[[Joystiq]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=11 September 2012 |accessdate=26 November 2012}}</ref> An [[asymmetry|asymmetrical multiplayer mode]], it pits two teams (with different gadgets, playing as spies or mercenaries) against each other. Spies, in [[third-person perspective]], are equipped with smoke grenades and [[Stun grenade|flashbangs]] and are tasked with hacking computer stations heavily guarded by mercenaries. Mercenaries, in [[First person (video games)|first person]], can access lethal and longer-range weapons despite being unable to stealth-kill enemies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/09/05/14-must-read-survival-tips-for-splinter-cell-blacklists-spies-vs-mercs/|title=14 must-read survival tips for Splinter Cell: Blacklist's 'Spies vs. Mercs'|first=Dan|last=Hsu|work=[[VentureBeat]]|date=September 5, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> The mode has two varieties: Classic, supporting teams of 2v2, and Blacklist, supporting 4v4 action.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/05/07/15-things-to-know-about-splinter-cell-blacklist-co-op-spies-vs-mercs|title=15 Things To Know About Splinter Cell Blacklist Co-op, Spies vs. Mercs|first=Mitch|last=Dyer|work=[[IGN]]|date=May 7, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxm.co.uk/44864/splinter-cell-blacklists-online-features-revealed-progression-unlocks-and-fourth-echelon/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist's online features revealed: progression, unlocks and Fourth Echelon|date=January 16, 2013|publisher=[[Official Xbox Magazine]]|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref>
''Blacklist'' also has a co-operative multiplayer mode, where each mission can be accessed by talking with the crew of the ''Paladin''. Crew members offer a variety of missions and requirements for completing them, and players play as Fisher or his colleague Briggs; both have the same abilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/previews/tom-clancy-s-splinter-cell-blacklist-co-op-and-multiplayer-impressions|title=Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Blacklist Co-Op and Multiplayer Impressions|first=Robert|last=Workman|work=GameZone|date=July 14, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> The game has a total of 14 missions, with [[split screen (computer graphics)|split-screen]] play supported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/splinter-cell-blacklist-co-op-gameplay-walkthrough/|title=Splinter Cell Blacklist Co-op Gameplay Walkthrough|first=Tom|last=Ivan|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=August 13, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> In addition to co-op and Spies vs. Mercs, ''Blacklist'' has other multiplayer modes including Uplink control, Team Deathmatch, and Extraction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/originals/splinter-cell-blacklist-spies-vs-mercs-multiplayer-tips-for-fun-winning/2|title=Splinter Cell Blacklist Spies vs Mercs Multiplayer Tips for Fun & Winning|date=September 17, 2013|work=GameZone|first=Joe|last=Donato|accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref>
==Synopsis==
===Characters=== ''Blacklist'' again features Sam Fisher ([[Eric Johnson (actor)|Eric Johnson]]), a former Third Echelon Splinter Cell who is now the [[spymaster]] and commander of the newly installed Fourth Echelon. The game also sees the return of Fisher's old ally, Anna "Grim" Grímsdóttir ([[Kate Drummond]]), and new characters such as Isaac Briggs (Dwain Murphy) and Charlie Cole ([[David Reale]]). Several supporting characters from ''Conviction'' reappear, including Victor Coste (Howard Siegel), Patricia Caldwell ([[Mimi Kuzyk]]), and Andriy Kobin ([[Elias Toufexis]]), as well as interactive telephone conversations with Sarah Fisher ([[Victoria Sanchez (actress)|Victoria Sanchez]]).
==Plot== Following ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Conviction]]'', Third Echelon is dissolved and Sam Fisher works as a contractor for the private military corporation Paladin 9 Security, ran by his best friend Victor Coste. Terrorists assault the [[Andersen Air Force Base]] on [[Guam]], executing its commander and killing many American soldiers. Sam and Coste were caught in the crossfire and Coste is heavily injured. Soon afterwards, a faction known as the Engineers takes responsibility, announcing a series of attacks on the United States, the titular Blacklist, which will continue until the U.S. recalls [[United States military deployments|its troops deployed abroad]].
[[President of the United States|U.S. President]] Caldwell assigns Sam and his colleagues, tech expert Charlie Cole, CIA operative Isaac Briggs, and technical analyst Anna Grímsdóttir to Fourth Echelon, a new top secret special-ops and counter-terrorism unit. Charged with stopping the Engineers, the group uses the cargo plane ''Paladin'' as its command center. Fourth Echelon first aims to secure Andriy Kobin, an arms dealer (and Sam's past target) believed to possess information on the Engineers. Sam captures him at a militia headquarters in [[Benghazi]], and learns that he sold arms to the Engineers before the Guam attack. Tracking down Kobin's buyers, Sam infiltrates an Engineer camp at [[Iraq]]. He finds an executed U.S. soldier and learns from a video recording that the executioner and the leader of the Engineers is Majid Sadiq ([[Carlo Rota]]); a former [[MI6]] agent. The Engineers launch a strike on the site with a hacked military drone, and Sam narrowly escapes.
Believing that the next Blacklist attack is at [[Chicago]], Sam infiltrates the site of the attack and prevents the release of a biological toxin into the water supply. Grim identifies Fourth Echelon's next target, Iran-affiliated mercenary broker Reza Nouri (Sam Kalilieh) who may have supplied the Engineers. Sam infiltrates Nouri's mansion in [[Paraguay]], and extracts him as Iranian [[Quds Force|Qods Force]] commandos launch a simultaneous assault to kill Nouri. Nouri gives up intel on the Engineers in exchange for safety, leading to the discovery of an Engineer [[Clandestine cell system|sleeper cell]] in [[London]]. Sam infiltrates an abandoned mill where the cell is operating and finds files suggesting that Iran is behind the Engineers, as well as [[chemical weapon]]s and that Sadiq is on site. Sam is exposed to the chemical weapon when planting a tracker on a bomb, but continues to pursue Sadiq, leading to his incapacitation and capture by Sadiq. Briggs rescues Sam, but Sadiq escapes.
Due to the files recovered by Sam being made public by the President, the United States and Iran are headed towards war. Looking for more solid proof of Iran's involvement, Sam infiltrates Qods Force headquarters in [[Tehran]] and steals files from their servers. The files prove that Iran did not back the Engineers, and that the files he recovered at London were planted by the Engineers in order to lure the United States into a war. The President announces the new information and deescalates the US-Iranian tension.
The chemical weapon tracker leads to the [[Philadelphia]] city train yard, in time for the next Blacklist attack. Sam and Briggs deploy to the site and disarms all bombs. With multiple Blacklist attacks foiled, the Engineers increase the rate of the Blacklist attacks from once per week to once per day.
During this time, Nouri had given himself up to the CIA at the [[Guantanamo Bay detention camps]], and is providing false intel convincing the CIA of Iran's culpability, trying to reignite tensions. Briggs uses his CIA credentials to help Sam infiltrate Guantanamo Bay, allowing him to interrogate Nouri. Nouri says he is planted by Sadiq to distract the US government while Sadiq hijacks a fuel tanker, and that Sadiq is fully aware of Fourth Echelon. Sam and Briggs escape from Guantanamo Bay and reach the ''Paladin'' at [[Yucatán]]. There, they fend off an attack from a drug cartel, tipped off by a bounty on Fourth Echelon from Sadiq.
As Fourth Echelon heads to defend the next Blacklist attack, Sadiq disables ''Paladin'' with a computer virus, intending to crash it. With Kobin's help, ''Paladin'' is restarted, but Sadiq successfully executes his attack during this time; he rams the fuel tanker into the [[Sabine Pass]] [[LNG]] terminal, and uses the same virus to disable all fuel facilities in the Gulf Coast, aiming to burn up all fuel in the area. Sam enters the burning facility and reactivates the fire control systems, stopping the fire's spread. Sam captures an Engineer leader and learns about Sadiq's final target: the government bunker "Site F" under the [[Denver International Airport]].
The successful attack prompted the president to begin [[Continuity of government|continuity-of-government]] procedures, transferring key government personnel into secure bunkers. Sadiq had sleeper agents in Site F and took officials in Site F hostage, including the [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]]. As COG procedures activate, all government files are backed up at Site F, which are Sadiq's true goal. Disregarding the president's order, Fourth Echelon infiltrates Site F. Sadiq tortures the secretary of defense to authorize the file transfer, while Briggs turns himself in to Sadiq. When the secretary yields, Briggs intervenes and kills the secretary, halting Sadiq's plan.
Sadiq tries to flee Site F by stealing the ''Paladin'', using Briggs and the hostages as human shields. Sam, disguised as a hostage, helps [[Delta Force]] snipers to take down Sadiq's men. Sadiq tries to escape on foot, and Sam incapacitates him after a fight. Sadiq boasts that he has already won; if he dies, twelve nations supporting the Engineers will declare war on the U.S., and if he is tried, he will leak U.S. secrets. Although Sam spares Sadiq, he [[Extrajudicial detention|detains him]]. President Caldwell publicly covers Sadiq's imprisonment by announcing his death, and the game ends as Fourth Echelon continues its operations; in a [[post-credits scene]], a recovered Coste and Sam prepare to interrogate Sadiq.
===Co-op missions=== Intertwined with the main plot, the co-op missions begin with Fisher and Briggs infiltrating [[Kashmir, India|Kashmir]]. Finding a group of smugglers linked to the Engineers, Fisher and Briggs discover intelligence connecting them to the Russian intelligence organization Voron, before they escape during a drone attack.
Following a lead to a friendly missile base in [[Bangalore]], they find the Indian inhabitants dead and Voron agents stealing the warhead from a missile. Securing the missile and learning that the agents are led by a man named Cherski, Fisher and Briggs escape as the building is destroyed and Indian authorities arrive. Unaware of Cherski's identity, Fisher and Briggs track him to a Voron base in [[Chittagong]] and find him living in a nearby apartment. They breach Cherski's panic room and find two people; uncertain which one is Cherski, they begin interrogating both and learn about a secret base in Russia.
Fisher and Briggs reach an abandoned [[naukograd]], surviving a drone attack, and find a secure medical facility said to contain an OpSat (satellite uplink device used by Fourth Echelon operatives) with vital Voron information. Instead, the base contains a comatose man. Rescuing the man, Fisher and Briggs narrowly escape as the base self-destructs and return the patient to the ''Paladin''. Grim identifies him as Mikhail "Kestrel" Loskov and Kobin confirms his identity, noting that they have a history (detailed in ''Conviction''). When he questions Kobin (who asks if Kestrel's gunshot wound has put him into a coma), Fisher notes that no one had told Kobin how Kestrel had been incapacitated.
==Development== [[File:Jade Raymond Feb 2012-cropped.jpg|thumb|alt=Young, seated woman with long dark hair|Ubisoft Toronto founder Jade Raymond is the producer of ''Blacklist''.]] [[Ubisoft web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2009/07/06/ubisoft-opening-studio-in-toronto-continuing-to-take-over-canad/|title=Ubisoft opening studio in Toronto, continuing to take over Canada Raymond To Lead Ubisoft Toronto|first=Michael|last=McWhertor|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=August 31, 2009|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> It worked on a new installment of the ''Splinter Cell'' series, Works|first=David|last=Clayman|work=[[IGN]]|date=May 25, 2010|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> Maxime Béland, who had worked on ''Conviction'', was the game's creative director,<ref name="gama1"/> and in November 2010 Raymond confirmed that her studio was developing ''Splinter Cell 6''.<ref>{{cite web| accessdate=26 November 2012 |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2010-11-26-jade-raymond-making-splinter-cell-6 |title=Jade Raymond Making Splinter Cell 6 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |first=Wesley |last=Yin-Poole |date=26 November 2010}}</ref> Ubisoft Toronto was the game's lead developer, with assistance from Ubisoft Montreal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/splinter-cell-blacklist-hitting-spring-2013/1100-6380103/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist hitting spring 2013|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=June 4, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> [[Ubisoft Shanghai]] developed the game's co-operative multiplayer mode. The Toronto studio focused on the game's Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 versions, with the Wii U version developed by Ubisoft Shanghai.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-05-07-wii-us-splinter-cell-blacklist-is-being-developed-by-ubisoft-shanghai|title=Wii U's Splinter Cell: Blacklist is being developed by Ubisoft Shanghai|first=Martin|last=Robinson|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref>
In 2010, the series' fifth installment, ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Conviction|Conviction]]'', was released. Although it received generally positive reviews, it was criticized by series fans for lacking some features. Béland considered ''Conviction'' a "stepping stone" for him when he prepared for the development of ''Blacklist''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2012/09/12/splinter-cell-blacklist-builds-on-convictions-story-successes-and-failures/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist builds on Conviction’s story, successes and failures|first=Brenna|last=Hillier|work=[[VG247]]|date=September 12, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> The development team studied ''Conviction''{{'s}} reviews and feature lists, deciding to discard its "black-and-white" stealth approach, and also deciding to bring back the Spies vs. Mercs mode introduced in ''Pandora Tomorrow''. Béland called the mode's return "the easiest decision of [his] life", since the team considered its absence ''Conviction''{{'s}} greatest misstep.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/09/11/splinter-cell-blacklist-aims-to-take-convictions-promise-to-th/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist aims to take Conviction's promise to the next level and then some|first=Mike|last=Schramm|date=September 11, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2015|work=[[Joystiq]]}}</ref> Ubisoft sent questionnaires through [[Uplay]] to thousands of players to collect feedback on ''Conviction''{{'s}} new features.<ref name="EuroGComplex">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-04-23-raymond-splinter-cell-popularity-held-back-by-its-complexity|title=Raymond: Splinter Cell popularity held back by its complexity|first=Wesley|last=Yin-Poole|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=April 23, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> When players called ''Conviction''{{'s}} campaign weak and short, the team added a stronger storyline and greater character depth by introducing the Fourth Echelon and Fisher as a leader (a series first).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/01/30/how-ubisofts-designers-transformed-sam-fisher-into-a-panther-and-a-leader-in-splinter-cell-blacklist-interview/|title=How Ubisoft’s designers transformed Sam Fisher into a ‘panther’ and a leader in Splinter Cell: Blacklist (interview)|first=Dean|last=Takahashi|work=[[VentureBeat]]|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> To encourage repeat play the team introduced the aircraft hub and the strategic mission interface, a player menu.<ref name="GIStory"/>
{{Quote box|quote=Even though we do have core fans who are like, "Oh, I want to have more of this experience", when you play any other game that has stealth elements, they're all a lot more forgiving than Splinter Cell. |source= — Jade Raymond|width=33%}} According to Ubisoft Toronto founder Jade Raymond, the series had become too grueling and complicated for modern gamers, and its popularity had suffered relative to Ubisoft flagship franchises such as ''[[Assassin's Creed (series)|Assassin's Creed]]'' and ''[[Far Cry (series)|Far Cry]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/splinter-cells-popularity-is-held-back-by-its-complexity-says-blacklist-studio-head/|title=Splinter Cell's popularity is held back by its complexity, says Blacklist studio head|first=Phil|last=Savage|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=April 23, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> The Toronto studio hoped to introduce the franchise to a broader audience, while remaining tactical and hardcore for long-term series fans.<ref name="EuroGComplex"/> It introduced a perfectionist mode, significantly increasing the game's difficulty by removing some of Fisher's abilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/01/30/splinter-cell-blacklist-modernizes-chaos-theory|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist Modernizes Chaos Theory|first=Mitch|last=Dyer|work=[[IGN]]|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> The team also introduced accessible, action-oriented gameplay segments which would suit new players,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2013/06/14/splinter-cell-blacklist-sam-fisher-favors-shadows-over-gunplay/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist: Fisher favors shadows over gunplay|first=Catherine|last=Cai|work=[[VG247]]|date=June 14, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> crafting open-ended levels which could be reached with different approaches to broaden the variety of play.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/splinter-cells-complexity-hurting-its-popularity-says-raymond/1100-6407384/|title=Splinter Cell's complexity hurting its popularity, says Raymond|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=April 23, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> The developers re-worked the controls to increase gameplay fluidity, allowing players to automatically leap over objects and traverse a simplified environment.<ref name="GIStory">{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2012/07/17/directing-splinter-cell-an-interview-with-maxime-beland.aspx?PostPageIndex=2|title=Directing Splinter Cell: An Interview With Maxime Beland|first=Matt|last=Miller|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=July 17, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref>
During ''Blacklist''{{'s}} development, its team faced a variety of challenges. The first was to create stealth which was satisfying and fun for players. According to the team, players gain satisfaction from stealth with freedom and choices which allow them to develop a plan. Players must experiment, with each decision having consequences. Game director Patrick Redding compared it to the development of an ecosystem; the team designed a dynamic [[artificial intelligence]] which would react differently to players' actions, making levels feel alive and adding randomness. Encouraging the "panther" style of play (aggressive stealth), the team incorporated elements from the original ''Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell'' (where one mistake would abort a mission) and ''Conviction'' (where stealth seamlessly becomes combat). This approach, the team thought, could help players to feel like elite, silent predators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/splinter-cell-blacklist-and-the-challenges-of-stealth/1100-6406874/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist and the Challenges of Stealth|first=Maxwell|last=McGee|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=April 12, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref>
Series veteran [[Michael Ironside]] did not reprise his role as the voice of Sam Fisher. His part was played by [[Eric Johnson (actor)|Eric Johnson]], who also performed the motion capture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/gaming/2012/6/5/3066844/splinter-cell-blacklist-has-a-new-voice-for-sam-fisher-heres-what|title='Splinter Cell: Blacklist' has a new voice for Sam Fisher; here's what happened to Michael Ironside|first=Russ|last=Frushtick |date=June 5, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2015|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]}}</ref> In a ''Blacklist'' developer diary, Ironside said that he was passing the torch to another actor. According to Ubisoft executives the change was made to take advantage of new performance-capture technology to enrich the game experience, and Ironside assisted Johnson with the role.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/06/05/e3-2012-why-michael-ironside-wont-return-for-splinter-cell-blacklist|title=E3 2012: Why Michael Ironside Won't Return For Splinter Cell: Blacklist|first=Mitch|last=Dyer|work=[[IGN]]|date=June 4, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> [[Elias Toufexis]], voice and performance-capture actor for Andriy Kobin in ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Conviction|Splinter Cell: Conviction]]'', said that he would return for the new game.<ref>{{cite web|title=More Than Meets The Ears|url=http://blog.ubi.com/elias-toufexis-role-playing-column-june-2013/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609032608/http://blog.ubi.com/elias-toufexis-role-playing-column-june-2013/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 9, 2013|work=UbiBlog|publisher=[[Ubisoft]]|date=June 6, 2013|accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref>
Unlike ''Conviction'', the game would have no interactive torture sequences. Instead, players could choose whether to kill or incapacitate a target after interrogation. The system was not complex, and it was hoped that players would choose based on instinct. According to Béland, every player choice is gray and there are no right or wrong choices.<ref name="KTorture"/> However, the game demo has an interactive torture scene in which players can decide how deeply a knife penetrates a person's shoulder.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-01-30-splinter-cell-blacklists-torture-scene-is-cut|title=Splinter Cell Blacklist's torture scene is cut|first=Martin|last=Robinson|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> After a mixed-to-negative response, Ubisoft removed the scene from its final product.<ref>{{cite web|last=Conditt|first=Jessica|title=Torture scene removed from Splinter Cell: Blacklist, no one 'loved' it|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2013/01/30/torture-scene-removed-from-splinter-cell-blacklist-no-one-lov/|publisher=Joystiq|accessdate=30 January 2013}}</ref>
===Marketing=== ''Splinter Cell: Blacklist'' was introduced at [[E3 2012]]'s Microsoft press conference on June 4, 2012, for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], and [[Xbox 360]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/06/04/splinter-cell-blacklist-revealed-for-xbox/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist coming to Xbox 360, PC, PS3 in spring 2013 [Update]|author=JC Fletcher |date= June 4, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2015|work=[[Joystiq]]}}</ref> In February 2013, a [[Wii U]] version was rumored to be in development,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-02-27-splinter-cell-blacklist-sneaks-onto-wii-u-rumour|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist sneaks onto Wii U - rumour|first=Jeffery|last=Matulef|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=February 27, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> and Ubisoft confirmed the report two months later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-04-10-splinter-cell-blacklist-finally-confirmed-for-wii-u|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist finally confirmed for Wii U|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=April 10, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> Originally scheduled for release in early 2013, the game was pushed back to August on January 16, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/splinter-cell-blacklist-pushed-back-to-august-242526.phtml|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist pushed back to August|first=Jordan|last=Devore|work=[[Destructoid]]|date=January 16, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}</ref> On August 3, 2013, Ubisoft confirmed that the game had been declared [[Software release life cycle#Release to manufacturing (RTM)|gold]], indicating that it was being prepared for duplication and release.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/08/08/tom-clancys-splinter-cell-blacklist-has-gone-gold|title=Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Blacklist Has Gone Gold|work=[[IGN]]|first=Mitch|last=Dyer|date=August 3, 2013|accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref> ''Splinter Cell: Blacklist'' was released in North America on August 20 and in Europe three days later for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, Wii U, and Xbox 360.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2013/01/16/splinter-cell-blacklist-delayed-into-august/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist delayed into August|first=Stephany|last= Nunneley|date=January 16, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015|work=[[VG247]]}}</ref>
The Paladin Collector's Edition, a limited edition of the game, has a remote-controlled plane, the graphic novel ''Splinter Cell Echoes'', a Billionaire's Yacht co-op map, an Upper Echelon pack with a Dead Coast map, gold sonar goggles, and a limited-edition poster.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/01/25/flying-rc-plane-highlights-splinter-cell-blacklist-collectors-edition|title=Flying RC Planes Highlights Splinter Cell Blacklist's Collector's Edition|last=McCaffrey|first=Ryan|date=January 25, 2013|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref> ''Splinter Cell: Blacklist - Spider Bot'', a 2D puzzle game tie-in, was released for Android and iOS platforms on June 10, 2013 and is available on Google Play and the App Store respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2013/06/19/splinter-cell-blacklist-spider-bot-ios-game-lands-on-app-store|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist Spider-Bot iOS game lands on App Store}}</ref> ''Homeland'', [[downloadable content]] for the game, was released on September 26, 2013. It added a crossbow, several new costumes, and two new missions which can be completed alone or with another player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-09-26-splinter-cell-backlists-homeland-dlc-sneaks-out-today|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist's Homeland DLC sneaks out today|date=September 26, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2015|work=[[Eurogamer]]|first=Jeffery|last=Matulef}}</ref>

''Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist'' received positive reviews. The [[review aggregator]] website [[Metacritic]] rated the PlayStation 3 version 84 out of 100,<ref name=MCPS3 /> the Xbox 360 version 82 out of 100,<ref name=MCX360 /> the PC version 82 out of 100,<ref name=MCPC /> and the Wii U version 75 out of 100.<ref name="MCWIIU" />
The game's design was praised by most reviewers. Ryan McCaffrey of [[IGN]] praised the gameplay's variety and player options, which he thought made ''Blacklist'' the best installment in the series since ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory]]''. According to McCaffrey, the game was a satisfying stealth experience and an excellent, capable shooter (increasing its [[replay value]]). He noted that several segments forced players to use the Mark and Execute feature, frustrating players who favored stealth over action.<ref name="IGN"/> Ben Reeves of ''[[Game Informer]]'' praised the return and refinement of Mark and Execute, which he found satisfying, and praised the game's intense, varied mission design.<ref name="GI"/> Tom Bramwell of ''[[Eurogamer]]'' disliked the game's direction, particularly its action elements (which he compared to 2012's ''[[Hitman: Absolution]]'').<ref name="EuroG"/>
''Blacklist''{{'s}} campaign was also generally praised. According to IGN's McCaffrey, the game's story is superior to those of its predecessors: well-balanced and believable. He criticized Sam Fisher's new voice actor, who he thought failed to replicate Ironside's charm. Ben Reeves praised the story's plot twists and sympathetic characters.<ref name="GI"/> On the [[Joystiq]] blog, Xav De Matos liked the game's narrative urgency and engaging plot twists but criticized its rushed ending.<ref name="JoystiqReview"/> Simon Miller of VideoGamer.com called the game forgettable and boring, with Fisher's new voice actor failing to bring personality to the character.<ref name="VG"/> ''Eurogamer''{{'s}} Bramwell also criticized the game's lack of character development.<ref name="EuroG"/>
Its multiplayer features were praised; according to McCaffrey, the co-operative multiplayer mode had enough content for a separate game. Although he appreciated Spies vs. Mercs' faster pace, he found the mode less innovative than its predecessor.<ref name="IGN"/> Reeves partially agreed, describing the revived Spies vs. Mercs mode as refreshing, intense, and bloody.<ref name="GI"/> De Matos wrote that it was one of the best multiplayer modes he had ever experienced, and the ''Blacklist'' version had evolved and modernized while remaining creative.<ref name="JoystiqReview"/> Daniel Bloodworth of [[GameTrailers]] praised the game's satisfying co-op design, which tasks players to plan and coordinate strategy.<ref name="GT"/>
''Blacklist''{{'s}} graphics and lack of difficulty were criticized (the former likely due to the game still using [[Unreal Engine 2.5]] that Splinter Cell games since ''Chaos Theory'' have used). McCaffrey found the visuals unimpressive and most character models to be ugly; he also noted technical problems, such as screen-tearing and [[frame rate]] issues.<ref name="IGN"/> Bloodworth criticized the game's invisible wall and unresponsive controls in certain segments, although he thought those minor issues did not drag down its overall experience.<ref name="GT"/> McCaffrey noted that even when the game is played in perfectionist mode, it is less challenging than its predecessors. He thought ''Blacklist'' gave players too many rewards, making its universal-economy system a useless feature.<ref name="IGN"/> Bloodworth was puzzled by the game's unlock system, which he said hindered its credibility.<ref name="GT"/>
===Sales=== Ubisoft hoped that ''Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist'' would sell at least five million copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/blacklist-the-test-for-ubisoft-toronto-game-developers-1.1388627|title=Blacklist the test for Ubisoft Toronto game developers|work=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=August 20, 2013|accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref> The game debuted at number two on the UK retail software sales chart in its first week of release, behind ''[[Saints Row IV]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/08/27/saint-row-iv-beats-splinter-cell-blacklist-for-uk-number-one-3939051/|title=Saint Row IV beats Splinter Cell: Blacklist for UK number one|date=August 27, 2013|accessdate=August 4, 2015|work=[[Metro (magazine)|Metro]]}}</ref> It was August's fourth-bestselling game in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2013/09/13/npd-august-2013-3ds-tops-hardware-again-madden-25-clear-software-winner/|title=NPD August 2013: 3DS tops hardware again, Madden 25 clear software winner|first=Stephany |last=Nunneley|work=[[VG247]]|date=September 13, 2013|accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref> On October 16, 2013 Ubisoft announced that ''Blacklist'' had failed to meet sales expectations,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-10-16-ubisoft-splinter-cell-rayman-legends-missed-sales-targets|title=Ubisoft: Splinter Cell, Rayman Legends missed sales targets|last=Phillips|first=Tom|date=16 October 2013|work=[[Eurogamer]]|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref> and on November 13 it was announced that the game had sold two million copies worldwide.<ref name="SCB-Sales">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/splinter-cell-blacklist-underperforms-with-2-million-sold/1100-6416144/|title=Splinter Cell: Blacklist underperforms with 2 million sold|last=Makuch|first=Eddie|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=12 November 2013|accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref>

''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' (March 14, 1996). ==Fashion career== ===Early career=== When interviewing for jobs after graduation, Ford said that he had attended [[The New School]]'s Parsons division, but concealed that he graduated in architecture, and that his work at Chloé was a low-level public relations position. Despite his lack of experience in fashion, Ford called American designer Cathy Hardwick every day for a month in hopes of securing a job at her sportswear company. Hardwick eventually agreed to interview him. She later recalled the incident: "I had every intention of giving him no hope. I asked him who his favorite European designers were. He said, '[[Armani]] and [[Chanel]].' Months later I asked him why he said that, and he said, 'Because you were wearing something Armani'. Is it any wonder he got the job?" Ford worked as a design assistant for Hardwick for two years. In 1988, Ford moved to [[Perry Ellis (brand)|Perry Ellis]], where he knew both Robert McDonald, the company's president, and [[Marc Jacobs]], its designer, socially. He worked at the company for two years, but grew tired of working in American fashion.{{Citation needed |date=April 2016}} In a later interview with ''[[The New York Times]]'', he commented, "If I was ever going to become a good designer, I had to leave America. My own culture was inhibiting me. Too much style in America is tacky. It's looked down upon to be too stylish. Europeans, however, appreciate style."{{Cite web |url=http://www.fashionone.com/news/2014/09/29/touch-innuendo-tom-ford-springsummer-2015/ |title=A Touch of Innuendo at Tom Ford Spring/Summer 2015 |date=September 29, 2014 |website=[[Fashion One]] |access-date=April 8, 2016}}{{cite news |last=Parker |first=Ashley Joy |date=August 27, 2013 |title=This Week In Fashion History: The Rise And Rise Of Tom Ford's Empire |url=http://www.fashiontimes.com/articles/595/20130827/week-fashion-history-rise-tom-fords-empire.htm |website=Fashion Times |publisher=[[IBT Media]] |access-date=April 18, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426014328/http://www.fashiontimes.com/articles/595/20130827/week-fashion-history-rise-tom-fords-empire.htm |archivedate=April 26, 2016 |df= }} At the time, Italian fashion house [[Gucci]] was struggling financially and was seeking to strengthen its women's ready-to-wear presence as a part of a brand overhaul. The company's creative director, [[Dawn Mello]] said, "no one would dream of wearing Gucci". In 1990, Mello hired Ford as the brand's chief women's ready-to-wear designer and Ford moved to Milan. "I was talking to a lot of people, and most didn't want the job," Mello said. "For an American designer to move to Italy to join a company that was far from being a brand would have been pretty risky." Ford and his longtime partner, fashion journalist Richard Buckley, relocated to Milan that September. Ford's role at Gucci rapidly expanded; he was designing menswear within six months, and shoes soon after that. When Richard Lambertson left as design director in 1992, Ford took over his position, heading the brand's ready-to-wear, fragrances, image, advertising, and store design. In 1993, when he was in charge of designing eleven product lines, Ford worked eighteen-hour days. During these years, there were creative tensions between Ford and Maurizio Gucci, the company's chairman and 50% owner. According to Mello, "Maurizio always wanted everything to be round and brown, and Tom wanted to make it square and black." Though Maurizio Gucci wanted to fire Ford, [[Domenico De Sole]] insisted that he remain. Nonetheless, Ford's work during the early 1990s was primarily behind the scenes; his contributions to Gucci were overshadowed by those of Mello, who was the company's public face. ===Creative Director of Gucci and Saint Laurent=== [[File:Evening dress in Chinese dragon print satin by Tom Ford for Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche. Dress of the Year, 2004.jpg|405x405px|thumb|Evening dress by Tom Ford for Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche. Selected as [[Dress of the Year]] for 2004.]] In 1994, Ford was promoted to Creative Director of [[Gucci]]. In his first year at the helm, he introduced [[Halston]]-style velvet [[Low-rise (fashion)|hipsters]], skinny [[satin]] shirts and car-finish metallic patent boots.{{cite web|title=Gucci - Fall 1995 Ready-to-Wear|url=https://www.vogue.com/fashion-shows/fall-1995-ready-to-wear/gucci#collection|website=vogue.com|accessdate=21 September 2017}} In 1995, he brought in French [[Wardrobe stylist|stylist]] [[Carine Roitfeld]] and photographer [[Mario Testino]] to create a series of new ad campaigns for the company.{{cite news |last=Horyn |first=Cathy |date=April 20, 2015 |title=Tom Ford Gets Candid About His Years at Gucci |url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2015/04/tom-ford-gets-candid-about-his-years-at-gucci.html |work=[[New York (magazine)|The Cut]] |accessdate=April 7, 2016}} Between 1995 and 1996, sales at [[Gucci]] increased by 90%. At one point, Ford was the largest individual shareholder of Gucci stock and options. By 1999, the house, which had been almost bankrupt when Ford joined, was valued at more than $4 billion.{{cite news |last=Amed |first=Imran |date=September 26, 2013 |title=The Business of Being Tom Ford, Part I |url=http://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/people/the-business-of-being-tom-ford-part-i |work=[[The Business of Fashion]] |accessdate=April 7, 2016}} When Gucci acquired the house of [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]] (YSL) in 1999, Ford was named Creative Director of that label as well.{{cite news |last=Foxman |first=Ariel |date=February 11, 2016 |title=Tom Ford Wants to Change the Way We Shop |url=http://time.com/4217076/tom-ford-fashion-design/ |magazine=[[TIME]] |accessdate=March 5, 2016}} [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Saint Laurent]] did not hide his displeasure with Ford's designs, stating "The poor man does what he can".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/02/fashion/02laurent.html |work=The New York Times |first=Anne-Marie |last=Schiro |title=Yves Saint Laurent, Giant of Couture, Dies at 71 |date=June 2, 2008}} During his time as creative director for YSL, Ford nonetheless won numerous [[Council of Fashion Designers of America]] Awards. Like his work at Gucci, Ford was able to pull the classic fashion house back into the mainstream.{{Cite web |url=http://perfumesociety.org/discover-perfume/an-introduction/perfume-houses/tom-ford/ |title=Tom Ford – Perfume Society |website=Perfume Society |language=en-US |access-date=April 18, 2016}} His advertising campaigns for the YSL fragrances [[Opium (perfume)|Opium]] (with a red-haired Four people were hired to split the work Ford had done.{{cite news |last=Moran |first=Terry |title=Person of the Week: Tom Ford |url=http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/PersonOfWeek/story?id=131535 |work=[[ABC News]] |access-date=April 18, 2016}} ===Tom Ford label=== [[File:Tom Ford eyewear.gif|left|thumb|240x240px|Tom Ford eyewear]] [[File:Tom Ford Shop.jpg|left|thumb|277x277px|A Tom Ford boutique in Toronto]] After leaving [[Gucci]], Ford launched a line of menswear, beauty, eyewear, and accessories in 2006, named after himself, "Tom Ford". Controversial designer Tom Ford's 'unbelievably offensive' phallic pendants spark fury |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2872686/Is-rudest-necklace-Controversial-designer-Tom-Ford-s-unbelievably-offensive-phallic-pendants-spark-fury.html |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |accessdate=March 5, 2016}} Ford replied that "it was not meant to be a cross, it was a phallus" and "people read into things what they want to". ==Career as a film director== ===''A Single Man''=== [[File:ASingleManCastVenice66.jpg|thumb|Ford at the 66th Venice Film Festival, with ''[[A Single Man]]'s'' [[Julianne Moore]] and [[Colin Firth]], 2009]] In March 2005, Ford announced the launch of his film production company, Fade to Black. In 2009 he made his directorial debut with ''[[A Single Man]]'', based on the novel of the same name by [[Christopher Isherwood]]. The drama stars [[Colin Firth]] as an LA-based, gay college professor, alongside [[Julianne Moore]], [[Nicholas Hoult]] and [[Matthew Goode]]. The novel was adapted by [[David Scearce]] and Ford; Ford was also one of the producers. ''A Single Man'' premiered on September 11, 2009 at the [[66th Venice International Film Festival]], where it was nominated for top award the [[Golden Lion]]. Colin Firth was awarded the [[Volpi Cup]] as Best Actor for his performance. He won a [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role]], and was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Academy Award]],"Movie Guide" (February 12, 2010) ''Arlington Heights Daily Herald'' [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Golden Globe]],"Saucy Globes heavy on dark, sober themes" (January 17, 2010) ''Doylestown Intelligencer'' [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Male Lead|Independent Spirit Award]] and [[Screen Actors Guild Awards|Screen Actors Guild Award]] and won AFI Film of the Year and the GLAAD Media Award for Outstanding Film - Wide Release.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1315981/awards] Other nominations for the film included two further Golden Globe categories: Julianne Moore for Best Supporting Actress, and [[Abel Korzeniowski]] for Best Original Score. At the [[Independent Spirit Awards]], the film was nominated for Best First Feature and Best First Screenplay.[http://www.indiewire.com/article/tom_ford_the_film_has_turned_out_to_be_the_thing_i_am_most_proud_of_in_my_l "Spirit Awards 2010 | Tom Ford: 'I have always been obsessed by film.'", ''Indiewire'', February 17, 2013.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160425100631/http://www.indiewire.com/article/tom_ford_the_film_has_turned_out_to_be_the_thing_i_am_most_proud_of_in_my_l |date=April 25, 2016 }} Ford and Scearce also received a nomination for Best Adapted Screenplay at the Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards. ===''Nocturnal Animals''=== In 2015, Ford became attached to direct ''[[Nocturnal Animals]]'', an adaptation of the [[Austin Wright]] novel ''[[Tony and Susan]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tom-ford-teams-george-clooney-783758 |title=Tom Ford Teams with George Clooney for Thriller 'Nocturnal Animals' |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |author=Borys Kit |date=March 24, 2015 |accessdate=April 24, 2015}} The film was released in 2016. Ford has said in multiple interviews that his first lover was the artist [[Ian Falconer]],"Tom Ford, The Marquis de Sex" by Michael Hainey, ''GQ'', October 31, 2004, https://www.gq.com/story/tom-ford-gucci-designer-book"The Mourning After" by Peter Bowen, ''Filmmaker'', http://filmmakermagazine.com/archives/issues/winter2010/a-single-man.php who went on to write and illustrate the very popular [[Olivia (fictional pig)|Olivia the Pig]] children's book series. Ford maintains that he and Falconer are still good friends; decades after their breakup, Ford lent Falconer's last name to the title character of his first movie as a director, ''[[A Single Man]]''"Tom Ford Tells All" ''The Advocate'', November 9, 2009, https://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/film/2009/11/09/visionary-tom-ford (in the source novel the character originally had only had a first name). ===Politics=== Ford is a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]].
